Hi Tiago,

I did some testing of this setting using Escale’s email signature, and this is how I managed to get it to work --

Under System Configuration -> System Parameters -> click Add -> configure it as per below screenshot.
The “email signature” is a Custom Content denylist dictionary that includes the word “acidental” from the signature. You can add it under Denylists and Allowlists -> Denylists -> Custom Content -> Add. Please make sure you have this dictionary created already prior to creating this Contextual Detection Rule.


[cid:image001.png@01DACEE1.BBAEA7C0]

After the rule is configured and saved, please click the “Generate” button. Then, please scroll up the page and enable Contextual Detection, as per below:

[cid:image002.png@01DACEE2.4B9F1AE0]

What this means is that if a file or an email body contains the word “CONFIDENCIAL”, but in the proximity of 3000 characters it also has the word “acidental”, it will not trigger the policy.

Please make sure there are no Content Aware Policies in place that use individual Context Detection rules, as this global configuration won’t work if that’s the case.

Please let us know if it worked.

Thanks,
Natalie

Hi Tiago,

 

I did some testing of this setting using Escale’s email signature, and this is how I managed to get it to work --

 

Under System Configuration -> System Parameters -> click Add -> configure it as per below screenshot.

The “email signature” is a Custom Content denylist dictionary that includes the word “acidental” from the signature. You can add it under Denylists and Allowlists -> Denylists -> Custom Content -> Add. Please make sure you have this dictionary created already prior to creating this Contextual Detection Rule.

 

 



 

After the rule is configured and saved, please click the “Generate” button. Then, please scroll up the page and enable Contextual Detection, as per below:

 



 

What this means is that if a file or an email body contains the word “CONFIDENCIAL”, but in the proximity of 3000 characters it also has the word “acidental”, it will not trigger the policy.

 

Please make sure there are no Content Aware Policies in place that use individual Context Detection rules, as this global configuration won’t work if that’s the case.

 

Please let us know if it worked.

 

Thanks,

Natalie
